etymologies: Old English word, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch woord and German Wort, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin verbum ‘word’

definitions: a single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing, used with others (or sometimes alone) to form a sentence and typically shown with a space on either side when written or printed

examples.text: I don't like the word ‘unofficial’
so many words for so few ideas

shortDefinitions: single meaningful element of speech or writing

definitions: a single distinct conceptual unit of language, comprising inflected and variant forms.
shortDefinitions: single distinct conceptual unit of language

definitions: something spoken or written; a remark or statement

examples.text: his grandfather's words had been meant kindly
a word of warning

definitions: even the smallest amount of something spoken or written

examples.text: don't believe a word of it

shortDefinitions: even smallest amount of something spoken or written

definitions: angry talk

examples.text: her father would have had words with her about that

definitions: speech as distinct from action

examples.text: he conforms in word and deed to the values of a society that he rejects

definitions: a command, password, or signal

examples.text: someone gave me the word to start playing

definitions: communication; news

examples.text: I was afraid to leave Edinburgh in case there was word from the War Office
the prince sent word to the king asking him to send reinforcements

definitions: one's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person

examples.text: in court it would have been his word against mine

definitions: a promise or assurance

examples.text: everything will be taken care of—you have my word

definitions: the text or spoken part of a play, opera, or other performed piece; a script

examples.text: he had to learn his words

shortDefinitions: text or spoken part of play

definitions: a basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.
shortDefinitions: basic unit of data in computer

phrases.text: be as good as one's word
have a word in someone's ear
take the words out of someone's mouth

definitions: express (something spoken or written) in particular words

examples.text: he words his request in a particularly ironic way
a strongly worded letter of protest

phrases.text: be as good as one's word
have a word in someone's ear
take the words out of someone's mouth

definitions: used to express agreement or affirmation

examples.text: Word, that's a good record, man

shortDefinitions: used to express agreement or affirmation

phrases.text: be as good as one's word
have a word in someone's ear
take the words out of someone's mouth

etymologies: late Middle English (denoting unstated meaning): from Old French, or from Latin significantia, from significare ‘indicate, portend’

definitions: the quality of being worthy of attention; importance

examples.text: adolescent education was felt to be a social issue of some significance

shortDefinitions: quality of being worthy of attention

definitions: the meaning to be found in words or events

examples.text: the significance of what was happening was clearer to me than to her

shortDefinitions: meaning to be found in words or events

definitions: the extent to which a result deviates from that expected to arise simply from random variation or errors in sampling.
shortDefinitions: extent to which result deviates from that expected to arise simply from random variation

etymologies: late Old English twiges, from the base of two+ -s (later respelled -ce to denote the unvoiced sound); compare with once

definitions: two times; on two occasions

examples.text: the earl married twice
the tablets should be taken twice a day

definitions: double in degree or quantity

examples.text: I'm twice your age
an engine twice as big as the original

phrases.text: be twice the man that someone is

etymologies: Middle English: shortening of Old French especial ‘especial’ or Latin specialis, from species ‘appearance’ (see species)

definitions: better, greater, or otherwise different from what is usual

examples.text: they always made a special effort at Christmas

shortDefinitions: better, greater, or otherwise different from what is usual

definitions: exceptionally good or pleasant

examples.text: she's a very special person

definitions: (of a subject) studied in particular depth

examples.text: I wanted to take the Crusades as my special subject

definitions: belonging specifically to a particular person or place

examples.text: we want to preserve our town's special character

shortDefinitions: belonging specifically to particular person or place

definitions: designed or organized for a particular person, purpose, or occasion

examples.text: we will return by special coaches

shortDefinitions: designed or organized for particular person or occasion

definitions: used to denote education for students with particular educational requirements arising from physical or intellectual disability or behavioural difficulties.
shortDefinitions: denoting education for children with particular educational requirements

definitions: denoting a group consisting of matrices of unit determinant.
shortDefinitions: denoting group consisting of matrices of unit determinant

definitions: a thing, such as a product or broadcast, that is designed or organized for a particular occasion or purpose

examples.text: television's election night specials

definitions: a dish not on the regular menu at a restaurant but served on a particular day

examples.text: customers queue for such specials as vegetable lasagne

shortDefinitions: dish not on regular menu at restaurant but served on particular day

definitions: a person assigned to a special duty; a special constable or special correspondent

examples.text: when I went to arrest him he saw that I was a special

definitions: a product or service offered at a temporarily reduced price

examples.text: Mrs Hill was a careful shopper, choosing house brands and in-store specials

shortDefinitions: product or service offered at temporarily reduced price

definitions: a sudden violent shaking of the ground, typically causing great destruction, as a result of movements within the earth's crust or volcanic action.
shortDefinitions: sudden violent shaking of ground as result of movements within earth's crust or volcanic action

definitions: a great upheaval

examples.text: a political earthquake

definitions: causing difficulty or annoyance

examples.text: schools are removing troublesome pupils

skillful.error: No entry found matching supplied source_lang, word and provided filters

etymologies: Old English onweg, aweg ‘on one's way’ (see a-, way)

definitions: to or at a distance from a particular place, person, or thing

examples.text: she landed badly, and crawled away
they walked away from the vicarage in silence
we'll only be away for four nights

definitions: at a specified distance

examples.text: when he was ten or twelve feet away he stopped
we have had patients from as far away as Wales

definitions: at a specified future distance in time

examples.text: the wedding is only weeks away

definitions: towards a lower level; downwards

examples.text: in front of them the land fell away to the river

definitions: conceptually to one side, so as no longer to be the focus of attention

examples.text: the Museum has shifted its emphasis away from research towards exhibitions

definitions: (with reference to a sports fixture) at the opponents' ground

examples.text: Oh what fun it is to see the Mariners win away
we are away to Morecambe on Saturday

definitions: into an appropriate place for storage or safekeeping

examples.text: he put away the pistol

definitions: into non-existence

examples.text: Marie felt her distress ebbing away

definitions: constantly, persistently, or continuously

examples.text: there was Morrissey crooning away

definitions: (of a sports fixture) played at the opponents' ground

examples.text: tomorrow night's away game at Leicester

examples.text: the away side scored first
away fans chanted and cheered

definitions: an away match or win.

etymologies: Middle English: from Old Norse angr ‘grief’, angra ‘vex’. The original use was in the Old Norse senses; current senses date from late Middle English

definitions: a strong feeling of annoyance, displeasure, or hostility

examples.text: she could barely restrain her anger at this comment

definitions: fill (someone) with anger; provoke anger in

examples.text: she was angered by his terse answer
he was angered that he had not been told

etymologies: Old English spadu, spada, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch spade, German Spaten, also to Greek spathē ‘blade, paddle’

definitions: a tool with a sharp-edged, typically rectangular, metal blade and a long handle, used for digging or cutting earth, sand, turf, etc.
shortDefinitions: tool with sharp-edged metal blade and long handle, used for digging or cutting earth, etc.

definitions: a tool shaped like a spade but used for another purpose, especially one for removing the blubber from a whale.
shortDefinitions: tool of similar shape for another purpose

definitions: shaped like a spade

examples.text: a spade bit

definitions: dig over (ground) with a spade

examples.text: while spading the soil, I think of the flowers

definitions: move (soil) with a spade

examples.text: earth is spaded into the grave

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

etymologies: late 16th century: from Italian spade, plural of spada ‘sword’, via Latin from Greek spathē; compare with spade

definitions: one of the four suits in a conventional pack of playing cards, denoted by a black inverted heart-shaped figure with a small stalk.
shortDefinitions: one of four suits in conventional pack of playing cards

definitions: a card of the suit of spades.
a black person.
a track made of steel rails along which trains run.

examples.text: services were disrupted after an eight-year-old boy was spotted trespassing on the railway
a railway line

definitions: a set of tracks for other vehicles.
shortDefinitions: set of tracks for other vehicles

definitions: a network of tracks with the trains, organization, and personnel required for its working

examples.text: the carriage of freight on the railways

shortDefinitions: network of tracks with trains, organization

etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin salutare ‘greet, pay one's respects to’, from salus, salut- ‘health, welfare, greeting’; the noun partly from Old French salut

definitions: a gesture of respect or polite recognition, especially one made to or by a person when arriving or departing

examples.text: he raises his arms in a triumphant salute

shortDefinitions: gesture of respect or polite recognition

definitions: a prescribed movement, typically a raising of a hand to the head, made by a member of a military or similar force as a formal sign of respect or recognition

examples.text: he stood to attention but did not return the salute
he acknowledged the salute of the policeman on duty

shortDefinitions: prescribed movement made by member of a military as formal sign of respect or recognition

definitions: the discharge of a gun or guns as a formal or ceremonial sign of respect or celebration

examples.text: a twenty-one-gun salute

shortDefinitions: discharge of gun or guns as formal or ceremonial sign of respect or celebration

definitions: the formal performance of certain guards or other movements by fencers before engaging.
make a formal salute to

examples.text: don't you usually salute a superior officer?
he clicked his heels and saluted

definitions: greet

examples.text: he saluted her with a smile

definitions: show or express admiration and respect for

examples.text: we salute a truly great photographer

shortDefinitions: show or express admiration and respect for

definitions: hail (someone) as having a particular high office

examples.text: he was saluted king when he entered into Jerusalem

etymologies: Old English part (denoting a part of speech), from Latin pars, part-. The verb (originally in Middle English in the sense ‘divide into parts’) is from Old French partir, from Latin partire, partiri ‘divide, share’

definitions: an amount or section which, when combined with others, makes up the whole of something

examples.text: divide the circle into three equal parts
the early part of 1999
body parts

definitions: an element or constituent that is essential to the nature of something

examples.text: I was part of the family

definitions: a manufactured object assembled with others to make a machine; a component

examples.text: the production of aircraft parts

definitions: a division of a book, periodical, or broadcast serial

examples.text: this theme will be further explored in Parts Four and Five of the book
Part Four of the series

definitions: a measure allowing comparison between the amounts of different ingredients used in a mixture

examples.text: use a mix of one part cement to five parts ballast

definitions: some but not all of something

examples.text: the painting tells only part of the story

definitions: a point on or area of something

examples.text: hold the furthest part of your leg that you can reach

definitions: a region, especially one not clearly specified or delimited

definitions: a role played by an actor or actress

examples.text: she played a lot of leading parts

definitions: a melody or other constituent of harmony assigned to a particular voice or instrument in a musical work

examples.text: he coped well with the percussion part

shortDefinitions: melody assigned to voice or instrument

definitions: the contribution made by someone or something to an action or situation

examples.text: he played a key part in ending the revolt

definitions: the appropriate or expected behaviour in a particular role or situation; one's duty

examples.text: in such a place his part is to make good

definitions: abilities.
a line of scalp revealed in a person's hair by combing the hair away in opposite directions on either side; a parting

examples.text: the part in her hair was white and straight

definitions: (of two things) move away from each other

examples.text: his lips parted in a smile

definitions: divide to leave a central space

she parted the ferns and looked between them

definitions: leave someone's company

examples.text: there was a good deal of kissing before we parted
she can't bear to be parted from her daughter again

definitions: give up possession of; hand over

examples.text: even quite small companies parted with large sums

definitions: separate (the hair of the head on either side of the parting) with a comb

examples.text: his hair was centrally parted

definitions: to some extent; partly (often used to contrast different parts of something)

examples.text: the city is now part slum, part consumer paradise

etymologies: Old English hatian (verb), hete (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch haten (verb) and German hassen (verb), Hass ‘hatred’

definitions: have a strong aversion to (something)

examples.text: he hates flying

definitions: feeling a need to drink something

examples.text: the Guides were hot and thirsty

shortDefinitions: having or showing strong desire for something

examples.text: she's not even looking at you. Stop being so thirsty

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, ‘something undertaken’, feminine past participle (used as a noun) of entreprendre, based on Latin prendere, prehendere ‘to take’

definitions: a project or undertaking, especially a bold or complex one

examples.text: a joint enterprise between French and Japanese companies

definitions: initiative and resourcefulness

examples.text: success came quickly, thanks to a mixture of talent, enterprise, and luck

examples.text: a state-owned enterprise

examples.text: an economic environment which encourages enterprise
local enterprise agencies

etymologies: Old English frēosan (in the phrase hit frēoseth ‘it is freezing’), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vriezen and German frieren, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin pruina ‘hoar frost’ and frost

definitions: (with reference to a liquid) turn or be turned into ice or another solid as a result of extreme cold

examples.text: in the winter the milk froze
frost freezes water that has seeped into joints

shortDefinitions: turn or be turned into ice

definitions: become or cause to become blocked, covered, or rigid with ice

examples.text: the pipes had frozen
the ground was frozen hard

shortDefinitions: become blocked or covered with ice

definitions: be so cold that one feels near death (often used hyperbolically)

examples.text: you'll freeze to death standing there

definitions: (of the weather) be at or below freezing

examples.text: at night it froze again

definitions: deprive (a part of the body) of feeling, especially by the application of a chilled anaesthetic substance.
shortDefinitions: deprive part of body of feeling

definitions: stare coldly at (someone); treat coldly

examples.text: she would freeze him with a look when he tried to talk to her

definitions: store (something) at a very low temperature in order to preserve it

examples.text: the cake can be frozen

definitions: (of food) be able to be preserved at a very low temperature

examples.text: this soup freezes well

definitions: become suddenly motionless or paralysed with fear or shock

examples.text: she froze in horror

definitions: stop moving when ordered

examples.text: she came out with a revolver and told the boys to freeze

definitions: hold (something) at a fixed level or in a fixed state for a period of time

examples.text: new spending on defence was to be frozen

definitions: prevent (assets) from being used for a period of time

examples.text: the charity's bank account has been frozen

definitions: stop (a moving image) at a particular frame when filming or viewing

examples.text: the camera will set fast shutter speeds to freeze the action

definitions: (of a computer screen) become temporarily locked because of system problems.
an act of holding or being held at a fixed level or in a fixed state

examples.text: workers faced a pay freeze

shortDefinitions: act of freezing something at fixed level

definitions: a period of frost or very cold weather

examples.text: the big freeze surprised the weathermen

etymologies: Old English candel, from Latin candela, from candere ‘be white or glisten’

definitions: a cylinder or block of wax or tallow with a central wick which is lit to produce light as it burns

examples.text: the candle flickered in the cold night air
an iced cake with nine lighted candles on it

definitions: a unit of luminous intensity, superseded by the candela.

phrases.text: be able to hold a candle to
the game's not worth the candle

definitions: (of a poultry breeder) test (an egg) for freshness or fertility by holding it to the light

examples.text: the egg was candled—it was fertile

phrases.text: be able to hold a candle to
the game's not worth the candle

etymologies: Old English mapel (as the first element of mapeltrēow, mapulder ‘maple tree’); used as an independent word from Middle English

definitions: a tree or shrub with lobed leaves, winged fruits, and colourful autumn foliage, grown as an ornamental or for its timber or syrupy sap.

notes.text: Genus Acer, family Aceraceae: many species, including the common European field maple (A. campestre) and the North American sugar maple (A. saccharum)

shortDefinitions: tree or shrub with lobed leaves, winged fruits, and colourful autumn foliage

etymologies: Middle English: alteration (by association with either) of Old English nawther, contraction of nāhwæther (from nā ‘no’ + hwæther ‘whether’)

notes.text: The use of neither with another negative, as in I don't like him neither or he's not much good at reading neither is recorded from the 16th century onwards, but is not thought to be good English. This is because it is an example of a double negative, which, though standard in some other languages such as Spanish and found in many dialects of English, is not acceptable in standard English. In the sentences above, either should be used instead. For more information, see double negative. When neither is followed by nor, it is important in good English style that the two halves of the structure mirror each other: she saw herself as neither wife nor mother rather than she neither saw herself as wife nor mother. For more details, see either

definitions: used before the first of two (or occasionally more) alternatives (the others being introduced by ‘nor’) to indicate that they are each untrue or each does not happen

examples.text: unlike her friends, she is neither a snob nor a gossip
he neither answered them nor looked at them

shortDefinitions: used before first of two alternatives to indicate that they are each untrue

definitions: used to introduce a further negative statement

examples.text: he didn't remember, and neither did I

shortDefinitions: used to introduce further negative statement

phrases.text: neither one thing nor the other

notes.text: The use of neither with another negative, as in I don't like him neither or he's not much good at reading neither is recorded from the 16th century onwards, but is not thought to be good English. This is because it is an example of a double negative, which, though standard in some other languages such as Spanish and found in many dialects of English, is not acceptable in standard English. In the sentences above, either should be used instead. For more information, see double negative. When neither is followed by nor, it is important in good English style that the two halves of the structure mirror each other: she saw herself as neither wife nor mother rather than she neither saw herself as wife nor mother. For more details, see either

definitions: not the one nor the other; not either

examples.text: neither side of the brain is dominant over the other

shortDefinitions: not one nor other of two people or things

phrases.text: neither one thing nor the other

notes.text: The use of neither with another negative, as in I don't like him neither or he's not much good at reading neither is recorded from the 16th century onwards, but is not thought to be good English. This is because it is an example of a double negative, which, though standard in some other languages such as Spanish and found in many dialects of English, is not acceptable in standard English. In the sentences above, either should be used instead. For more information, see double negative. When neither is followed by nor, it is important in good English style that the two halves of the structure mirror each other: she saw herself as neither wife nor mother rather than she neither saw herself as wife nor mother. For more details, see either

definitions: not the one nor the other of two people or things

shortDefinitions: not the one nor the other of two people or things
